name: Utopian Slumps: The Collingwood Years
description:
Utopian Slumps: The Collingwood Years is a retrospective publication documenting the exhibitions and events that took place during the gallery's non-profit years from 2007 to 2009.

Designed by Chase & Galley, the publication includes artist pages from Amber Wallis, Brendan Huntley, The Changes, Damp, Dan Moynihan, Jake Walker, Mark Rodda, Ry Haskings and Tristan Ceddia. The visual content is interspersed with texts from curators and arts writers including an interview between Hannah Mathews and Melissa  Loughnan, a short story from Amanda Maxwell, and essays from Amelia Douglas, Andrew Gaynor & Emma Langride, Helen Hughes, Rebecca Coates, Phip Murray, Rosemary Forde, Dunja Rmandic & Nella Thermelios and Meredith Turnbull.
 
Editorial team: Melissa Loughnan, Helen Hughes, Thomas Jeppe & Chris Barton
Design: Chase & Galley
Publisher: Utopian Slumps
224 pages, 25 x 17.5 x 2.5cm, colour, hard cover cloth bound 
Edition of 2000

Stockists:
Avenue Bookstore, Melbourne
Brunswick Bound, Melbourne
Gleebooks, Sydney
Metropolis, Melbourne
NGV Bookshop, Melbourne
Queensland Art Gallery Shop, Brisbane
RMIT Bookshop, Melbourne
St Heliers Store & Gallery, Melbourne

name: Don Carlos
description:
DON CARLOS
by Thomas Jeppe
designed by Black & White, Los Angeles
published by Surpllus
18.5 x 13.4 x 0.6cm

An interview with Don Carlos Ashida, Mexico's biggest seashell collector, featuring approximately 25 colour illustrations.

Conducted in Guadalajara in 2012, the discussion broaches themes of collecting strategies, aesthetic hierarchies, family dynamics, ethical limits, parallel approaches to art and nature, and the taxonomical urge.  

Don Carlos forms an accompaniment to Thomas Jeppe's 2013 exhibition at Utopian Slumps, 'Seaside Vernacular'.

Available for pre-order now, shipping to commence on Friday 26 April 2013.

name: Flormal
description:
Nieves

Flormal Zine - Misha Hollenbach - White

The tranquility and formality of floral arrangements is juxtaposed with Misha Hollenbach's wild, free flowing ink attacks creating an eerie sense of beauty and disruption in this new release from Innen Zines and Nieves.

Printed in black and white.
20 x 14 x 0.2cm

name: Discipline 1
description:
DISCIPLINE ISSUE 1

Discipline is a new, independent, Melbourne-based contemporary art journal. It has a focus on longer, research-based essays, interviews and artist pages. The first issue has been edited by Helen Hughes
and Nicholas Croggon, with a curated section of artist pages, interviews and essays guest edited by Amsterdam-based curator, Vivian Ziherl. It is 112 pages in full colour and has been designed by
Warren Taylor. 

Discipline aims to publish highly focused essays that take on, critically and intelligently, the full strength of contemporary artworks, working through their specific concepts, histories, politics and materialities.

Issue 1 features artist pages by Damiano Bertoli, Stuart Ringholt, Helen Johnson, Charlie Sofo, Mira Gojak, Sriwhana Spong, Jackson Slattery, Slave Pianos, Joshua Petherick, Annie Wu and Jessica McElhinney; essays by Francis Plagne on John Nixonʼs publishing and curatorial work in the 1980s; Patrice Sharkey and Liang Luscombe on Bianca Hesterʼs 2010 ACCA exhibition; Connal Parsley on Christian Thompson; Fayen dʼEvie on Fixing Broken Windows theory and the art of Pat Foster and Jen Berean; Ash Kilmartin on Olivia Barrettʼs 2010 curated exhibition Hotel Theory; David Homewood on seriality and Marco Fustinato; Nicholas Croggon on Graham Lambkin and the Shadow Ring; Matt Griffin on Pollywaffles; and Michael Ascroft on Matthew Collingsʼs art criticism; a curated section on art in its social moment by Vivian Ziherl (featuring Valeska Gert, Nine Yamamoto-Masson, Rebecca Cleman, Matthew Lutz-Kinoy and Ben Kinmont); book reviews by Helen Johnson and Sarinah Masukor; interviews by Thomas Jeppe with Joaquin Segura; and Shelley McSpedden with Raafat Ishak
and Tom Nicholson; and the first chapter of an ongoing novel that will unfold in later issues of Discipline by S.T. Lore

Discipline 1, Winter 2011
Editors: Helen Hughes and Nicholas Croggon
Guest Editor: Vivian Ziherl
Design: Warren Taylor
Publisher: Helen Hughes
112 pages, 30 x 21 cm, colour, perfect bound
Edition of 1000

name: Bags, Bottles, Newspapers
description:
Bags, Bottles, Newspapers is a set of postcards documenting Lauren Berkowitz's important installations from 1994, 'Bags', 'Bottles' and 'Newspapers'.

Published by Lauren Berkowitz, 1994
Text by Natalie King 
Design by Fabio Ongarato Design 
ISBN 0 646 20240 5 
Edition of 300
18 x 13 x 2cm

name: Holey Hole
description:
This self published artist book by Misha Hollenbach accompanied his 2011 solo exhibition of the same title. 

Holy Hole represents a shift in Hollenbach’s imagery, from a subversive iconography of pop culture to a fascination with both epic and humble architectural monuments, on and in the ground.

Text: Timothy Moore
Design: Misha Hollenbach 
Publisher: Dawn Press for Misha Hollenbach
28 pages in grey and yellow, 29 x 21 cm 
Edition of 20 each

name: Soundtracks
description:
This self published artist book by Dylan Martorell was produced with assistance from Asialink for his participation in the 2011 Jakarta Biennale. It contains essays and documentation of Martorell's Biennale street performances and installations.

Text: Amelia Barikin and Christopher L G Hill 
Design: Rona Narendra
Publisher: Dylan Martorell 
28 pages, signed and hand numbered 
29.5 x 20.5 cm 
Edition of 50

dylanmartorell.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/booklet.pdf

name: Duppy Housing
description:
This self published artist book by Dylan Martorell accompanied his 2010 solo exhibition of the same title at Utopian Slumps.

The exhibition title is a play on the album title ‘Dub Housing’ by Pere Ubu, changing ‘dub’ to ‘duppy’, which means ‘ghost’ or ‘double’ in Jamaican Patois. For Duppy Housing, Martorell re-housed his personal speaker collection within a variety of found objects, including basket balls, bread, baskets, plastic bags, tubes, bike helmets and dirt. His re-housed speakers, handmade electronic instruments, costumed figures and wall works combined to explore notions of electricity, vegetable-powered sound, sine waves and sound system mobility. 

Text: Christopher L.G. Hill 
Publisher: Dylan Martorell
28 pages, black and white, signed and hand numbered
29.5 x 20.5 cm 
Edition of 50

name: Musique Povera
description:
This self published artist book by Dylan Martorell accompanied his 2010 solo exhibition of the same title at the Heide Museum of Modern Art Project Space.

In Musique Povera Martorell presented a number of his hand-made musical instruments built from found materials such as discarded tins, plant matter, wood, rocks and metal, and displays a series of drawings on plywood that also functioned as musical compositions. 

Text: Sue Cramer and Jack Jeweller 
Publisher: Dylan Martorell
28 pages, black and white, signed and hand numbered
29.5 x 20.5 cm 
Edition of 50
